slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.content:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  1. Identify different types of image noise
  2. Apply spatial domain smoothing filters
  3. Implement frequency domain filtering
  4. Use edge-preserving filters for denoising
  5. Apply sharpening techniques to enhance edges

slides.title: Noise in Images
slides.content: Understanding image degradation

slides.title: Types of Image Noise
slides.content:
Gaussian Noise
Additive, bell-shaped distribution
Salt & Pepper
Random black/white pixels

slides.title: Noise Characteristics
slides.content:
Additive Noise

$$g(x,y) = f(x,y) + n(x,y)$$

  • Gaussian noise
  • Uniform noise

Multiplicative Noise

$$g(x,y) = f(x,y) \cdot n(x,y)$$

  • Speckle noise
  • Film grain

knowledgeCheck.question: What type of noise is best removed by a median filter?
knowledgeCheck.answer: Salt and pepper (impulse) noise, because the median operation ignores extreme outlier values.

slides.title: Edge-Preserving Filters
slides.content: Smoothing without blurring edges

slides.title: Bilateral Filter
slides.content:
Bilateral Filter: Combines spatial proximity AND intensity similarity weights.

$$w(i,j,k,l) = \exp\left(-\frac{(i-k)^2+(j-l)^2}{2\sigma_s^2}\right) \cdot \exp\left(-\frac{|I(i,j)-I(k,l)|^2}{2\sigma_r^2}\right)$$

knowledgeCheck.question: Why does the bilateral filter preserve edges while smoothing?
knowledgeCheck.answer: It uses intensity similarity weighting - pixels with very different intensities (across edges) receive low weights, so edges are not blurred.

slides.title: Adaptive Filtering
slides.content: Adaptive filters adjust their behavior based on local image statistics (variance, mean).

Laplacian
[[ 0,-1, 0],

[[-1, 0, 1],

slides.title: Sharpening Techniques
slides.content:
Unsharp Masking:

$$g = f + k \cdot (f - f_{blurred})$$

where k controls sharpening strength

slides.title: Edge Detection
slides.content: Comparison of Sobel, Prewitt, and Canny edge detectors

knowledgeCheck.question: What makes the Canny edge detector superior to simple gradient methods?
knowledgeCheck.answer: Canny uses non-maximum suppression and hysteresis thresholding to produce thin, connected edges with reduced noise sensitivity.

slides.title: Filter Implementation
slides.content:
import cv2
import numpy as np

img = cv2.imread('image.jpg', 0)

# Gaussian blur
blurred = cv2.GaussianBlur(img, (5,5), 1.5)

# Median filter (good for salt & pepper)
median = cv2.medianBlur(img, 5)

# Bilateral filter (edge-preserving)
bilateral = cv2.bilateralFilter(img, 9, 75, 75)

# Sharpening with Laplacian
laplacian = cv2.Laplacian(img, cv2.CV_64F)
sharpened = img - 0.5 * laplacian

slides.title: Summary
slides.content: Key Takeaways

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.content:
1. Noise types: Gaussian (additive), salt & pepper (impulse), speckle (multiplicative)
  2. Smoothing filters: Mean, Gaussian, median - trade-off between noise reduction and blur
  3. Low-pass: Removes high frequencies (noise, edges)
  4. Bilateral filter: Edge-preserving smoothing using intensity similarity
  5. High-pass/sharpening: Enhances edges using Laplacian or unsharp masking
  6. Edge detection: Canny provides best results with non-maximum suppression
